title: Ruth Davidson quits as leader of Scottish Conservatives
text:
Ruth Davidson, the departing leader of the Scottish Tories | Peter Summers/Getty Images Ruth Davidson quits as leader of Scottish Conservatives Davidson is widely credited as having saved the 2017 election for Theresa May

LONDON — Ruth Davidson quit Thursday as the Scottish Conservatives’ leader with a thinly veiled swipe at Boris Johnson over his approach to Brexit.

The Tory MSP said she had been struggling to juggle family life with her political responsibilities and wanted to spend more time with her new son.

But she also noted that she had wanted to deliver on Brexit in a way that would "mitigate risks" for Scottish business, despite the prime minister insisting he is prepared to take the U.K. out of the EU without a deal.

Speaking at a press conference, Davidson warned MPs who want to prevent a no-deal exit on October 31 that they must back any renegotiated deal the prime minister can secure. “You have had three opportunities [to vote for a deal], you blew every one of them, don’t blow a fourth,” she said.

The resignation of the most high-profile Tory outside of Westminster increases the pressure on Johnson to get a deal since Davidson said the prime minister had “categorically assured” her he intends to secure an agreement with Brussels.

Her decision to quit comes as MPs wanting to avoid a no-deal Brexit grapple with their options after Johnson announced Wednesday that he planned to suspend parliament for several weeks, a move widely interpreted as a bid to squeeze the time available to MPs to use parliamentary procedure to prevent Britain from leaving the EU with no agreement in place.

In her resignation letter, Davidson, who will remain as an MSP until 2021, thanked colleagues for their support since she gave birth to her son, Finn, almost a year ago.

"As I look to the future, I see the Scottish Election due in 2021 and a credible threat from our opponents to force a general election before then," she wrote.

"Having led our party through seven national elections and two referenda, I know the efforts, hours and travel required to fight such campaigns successfully. I have to be honest that where the idea of getting on the road to fight two elections in 20 months would once have fired me up, the threat of spending hundreds of hours away from my home and family now fills me with dread. That is no way to lead."

She insisted she would "continue to support the prime minister" but noted: "While I have not hidden the conflict I have felt over Brexit, I have attempted to chart a course for our party which recognizes and respects the referendum result, while seeking to maximize opportunities and mitigate risks for key Scottish businesses and sectors."

Davidson has been a vocal critic of Johnson and backed Jeremy Hunt in the recent Conservative leadership contest. She insisted she would not back a no-deal Brexit just after Johnson became prime minister last month.

She was also said to have been angered after he sacked her ally David Mundell as secretary of state for Scotland. Meanwhile, Johnson is seen as toxic by voters north of the border, where 62 percent of voters opted to stay in the EU in 2016.

Davidson issued a warning in her resignation statement that the U.K. would only be able to unite in the wake of the Brexit vote if those on either side of the political debate respect each other.

“Two referenda have split Scotland and, indeed, opinion in the U.K. I am convinced that referenda should be used to affirm public opinion but not as a way for political leaders to fail to lead," she said.

“Respect is what missing from our debates and without respect you cannot understand and you cannot unite which is what we in Scotland and the U.K. need to do.”

Davidson is widely credited as having saved the 2017 election for Theresa May after 13 Tory MPs were elected in Scottish constituencies — the highest number in decades.

The party also overtook Labour as the second largest party in Holyrood under her tenure.
